    Tutorial for enrichment analysis and fine-mapping with functional priors

    Kaixuan Luo, Alan Selewa

    enrichment_finemapping_tutorial.Rmd

    In this tutorial, we perform enrichment analysis and fine-mapping (using TORUS + SuSiE) on a small GWAS dataset.

    We use a reference genotype panel from European population (1KG).

    If you are in the He lab, you can load the EUR_variable_1kg.rds file from RCC.

    We need the bigsnpr package for this tutorial.

    library(bigsnpr)
bigSNP <- snp_attach(rdsfile = '/project2/xinhe/1kg/bigsnpr/EUR_variable_1kg.rds')

    Otherwise, you will need to obtain your own genotypes in PLINK format (bed/bim/fam) and use readBed() from the bigsnpr package to create the .rds file below.

    Load the packages. We need the susieR package to run finemapping.

    library(mapgen)
library(susieR)

    First we run process_gwas_sumstats() to load and process the summary statistics. The summary statistics file could be in either tab or comma delimited. We need the following columns in the summary statistics:

    • chromosome
    • position (base pair position, we current only support hg19!)
    • beta (if you have Odds Ratio, you will need to transform it to log(Odds Ratio))
    • standard error (SE)
    • reference allele
    • association/effect allele
    • SNP ID (rsID, or chr:position:a1:a2)
    • p-value

    Load the reference LD blocks from European 1KG.

    data('Euro_LD_Chunks', package='mapgen')

    Cleans GWAS summary statistics, adds metadata.

    gwas_file <- system.file("extdata", "test_sumstats.txt.gz", package="mapgen")
gwas <- process_gwas_sumstats(gwas_file, 
                              chr='chr', pos='position_b37', 
                              beta='bcac_onco2_beta', se='bcac_onco2_se',
                              a0='a0', a1='a1', 
                              snp='phase3_1kg_id', pval='bcac_onco2_P1df_Wald',
                              bigSNP=bigSNP,
                              LD_Blocks=LD_Blocks)

    Check that the output is cleaned and has appropriate columns:

    gwas[,c('chr','pos','beta','se','snp','pval','zscore')]

    Next, we must perform enrichment analysis with TORUS, which requires annotation files in .bed format. Use the prepare_torus_input_files() function, which takes the previous output, and annotation bed files. Your bed file should contain only 3 columns (chr, start, end) and chromosomes should be just the number (no “chr”).

    Currently only hg19/b37 coordinates are accepted. You will get wrong results if you use hg38/other.

    bed_annotations_dir <- system.file("extdata", "test_bed_dir/", package="mapgen")
annotation_bed_files <- list.files(path = bed_annotations_dir, pattern = "*.bed", full.names = TRUE)
torus.files <- prepare_torus_input_files(gwas, annotation_bed_files, torus_input_dir = "./torus_input")

    Now that the appropriate files have been generated, let’s run TORUS.

    run_torus() with option = "est-prior" returns a list with: enrichment estimates (log odds ratio) and 95% confidence intervals of each annotation, and SNP-level priors using the enrichment estimates. If you only want to enrichment estimates without computing SNP-level priors, you can set option = "est".

    torus.result <- run_torus(torus.files$torus_annot_file, 
                          torus.files$torus_zscore_file,
                          option = "est-prior",
                          torus_path = "torus") # set the path to 'torus' executable.

torus.enrich <- torus.result$enrich
torus.prior <- torus.result$snp_prior

    TORUS also gives us the uncertainty of whether each locus contains a causal variant or not. We run run_torus() with option = "fdr" to get the probability of each locus containing a causal variant.

    torus.fdr <- run_torus(torus.files$torus_annot_file, 
                       torus.files$torus_zscore_file,
                       option = "fdr",
                       torus_path = "torus")$fdr

    Lets add the TORUS SNP-level priors to our summary statistics.

    sumstats.for.susie <- prepare_susie_data_with_torus_result(sumstats = gwas, 
                                                           torus_prior = torus.prior)

    We see we have a new column called torus_prior.

    sumstats.for.susie[,c('chr','pos','beta','se','snp','pval','zscore','torus_prior')]

    You could limit loci with GWAS p-value cutoff (e.g. pval < 5e-8).

    If you want to limit loci with FDR cutoff, you can set the parameter fdr_thresh, which is the FDR associated with each locus obtained from running run_torus() with option = "fdr". We set it to 1 here just to keep all loci. You could lower this or just use default (FDR < 10%).

    sumstats.for.susie <- prepare_susie_data_with_torus_result(sumstats = gwas, 
                                                           torus_prior = torus.prior, 
                                                           torus_fdr = torus.fdr, 
                                                           fdr_thresh = 1)

    With this data frame, we can perform fine-mapping using SuSiE, you will need the susieR package for the steps below.

    We use run_finemapping() with SNP-level priors computed from TORUS based on enrichment estimates. Note that we ran SuSiE with L = 1 here, meaning we assumed there is at most 1 causal variant per SNP. This step could take a while if chunks contain many SNPs (\(O(n^2)\) where n is # of SNPs).

    susie_finemap_L1 <- run_finemapping(sumstats = sumstats.for.susie, 
                                    bigSNP = bigSNP, 
                                    priortype = 'torus', 
                                    L = 1)

    susie_finemap_L1 is a list of SuSiE results, one for each chunk/LD block. Usually we are just interested in the SuSiE PIP, which gives the probability of a SNP being causal. We can annotate our cleaned summary statistics with this information using merge_susie_sumstats()

    finemap.sumstats <- merge_susie_sumstats(susie_results = susie_finemap_L1, 
                                         sumstats = sumstats.for.susie)

    Lets look at the final cleaned, and finemapped summary statistics. We see we have a new column called susie_pip which is the probability of being causal.

    finemap.sumstats[,c('chr','pos','beta','se','snp','pval','zscore','torus_prior','susie_pip')]

    Developed by Kaixuan Luo, Alan Selewa, Sebastian Pott, Xin He.
